data.title: TypeScript syntax errors and auto complete not working
data.body:
With TypeScript versions 2.0.6 and 2.0.7 syntax errors and auto complete are not showing anymore. TypeScript versions 2.0.3 and 1.8 work. This issue appears when using either the workspace or the bundled TypeScript installation.

TypeScript compilation outside VS code works normal.

Occurs with the following configurations:
- TypeScript Version: 2.0.6-2.0.7
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1 - 1.7.1
- OS Version: Windows 8.1

tsconfig.json:
```
{
  "compilerOptions": {
    "noImplicitAny": false,
    "removeComments": false,
    "preserveConstEnums": true,
    "sourceMap": false,
    "declaration": false,
    "noResolve": true,
    "target": "es5"
  }
}
```

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install TypeScript version 2.0.6 or 2.0.7 in workspace, or use VS-code bundled (VS code 1.7.1)

data.title: Markdown renderer does not unescape \. in a link
data.body:
According to
https://enterprise.github.com/downloads/en/markdown-cheatsheet.pdf
and
http://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/syntax#backslash

\. should be used to escape a dot.

However, it looks like our hover renderer doesn't unescape the dot when in a link
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6461412/20001060/c705c6da-a27a-11e6-91ed-8a46fcd3821e.png)

data.title: Upgrade TSServer to version 2.0.7
data.body: - VSCode Version: 1.8.0-Insider

data.title: Too many binary downloads/installations
data.body:
Every two days or so there's a binary installer I have to download and install. The "restart and update" prompt is there almost every day. It's distracting.

I bet these updates are primarily updates to the scores of JS files in the package? e.g. not actually updates to any binaries, DLLs, etc.?

Can't you roll out the core JS updates a JS files, centrally, from a package repository, like you do with plugins? Does it really have to be a full binary distribution for every minor change?

data.title: Multiple target debugging: Not all targets started
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.7.1 (02611b40b24c9df2726ad8b33f5ef5f67ac30b44, 2016-11-03T13:53:14.822Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.1.7601
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|csharp|ms-vscode|1.4.1|
|debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|2.2.0|
|other extensions not|important for this issue|---|

---
When you set up your launch.json for multiple target debugging with **coreclr** and **chrome** configurations VSCode will - most of the time - only the **coreclr** application, and show the info bar, that I should configure my launch configuration but the configuration should be correct.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Setup a core and chrome launch configuration similar to this
```json
{
	"version": "0.2.0",
	"configurations": [
		{
			"name": "Launch Core",
			"type": "coreclr",
			"request": "launch",
			"preLaunchTask": "build",
			"program": "${workspaceRoot}\\bin\\Debug\\netcoreapp1.0\\MyWebApp.dll",
			"args": [],
			"cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
			"stopAtEntry": false,
			"internalConsoleOptions": "openOnSessionStart",
			"env": {
				"ASPNETCORE_ENVIRONMENT": "Development"
			}
		},
		{
			"name": "Launch Chrome",
			"type": "chrome",
			"request": "launch",
			"url": "http://localhost:5000",
			"sourceMaps": true,
			"webRoot": "${workspaceRoot}/wwwroot"
		},
		{
			"name": "dotnet + chrome",
			"type": "composite",
			"request": "launch",
			"configurationNames": [
				"Launch Core",
				"Launch Chrome"
			]
		}
	]
}
```
2. Run "dotnet + chrome"
3. You will see VSCodes info bar that I should set up the launch configuration

PS: It doesn't happen all the time. Sometimes it starts also the chrome configuration. But most of the time it shows the info.

![multiple target debugging](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7260053/19999213/4bb64bd4-a271-11e6-9269-a1cf765c704f.gif)

data.title: Multiple target debugging: Should be able to let targets depend on others
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.7.1 (02611b40b24c9df2726ad8b33f5ef5f67ac30b44, 2016-11-03T13:53:14.822Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.1.7601
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|csharp|ms-vscode|1.4.1|
|debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|2.2.0|
|other extensions not|important for this issue|---|

---
When you configure multi target debugging you should be able to configure which configuration depends on others. When you configure to debug a **coreclr web** application and you want to debug also the javascript via **Debugger for chrome**, the **chrome** configuration should be started after the **coreclr** has started. Because otherwise the browser starts although there is no running web server.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Setup a core and chrome launch configuration similar to this
```json
{
	"version": "0.2.0",
	"configurations": [
		{
			"name": "Launch Core",
			"type": "coreclr",
			"request": "launch",
			"preLaunchTask": "build",
			"program": "${workspaceRoot}\\bin\\Debug\\netcoreapp1.0\\MyWebApp.dll",
			"args": [],
			"cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
			"stopAtEntry": false,
			"internalConsoleOptions": "openOnSessionStart",
			"env": {
				"ASPNETCORE_ENVIRONMENT": "Development"
			}
		},
		{
			"name": "Launch Chrome",
			"type": "chrome",
			"request": "launch",
			"url": "http://localhost:5000",
			"sourceMaps": true,
			"webRoot": "${workspaceRoot}/wwwroot"
		},
		{
			"name": "dotnet + chrome",
			"type": "composite",
			"request": "launch",
			"configurationNames": [
				"Launch Core",
				"Launch Chrome"
			]
		}
	]
}
```
2. Run "dotnet + chrome"
3. You will see that that browser starts although the core application is still compiling or starting

Expected behavior:
The chrome configuration should start after the dotnet app has compiled and started.

PS: Most of the times the browser doesn't even start. Then I get the message, that I should configure my launch.json see Bug #14964

data.title: feature request: support disjunction/or in when-clauses for keybindings

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
request: support disjunction and grouping in when-clauses.

example:
```json
{ ..., "when": "(clause1 && clause2) || clause3" }
```
should be equivalent to:
```json
{ ..., "when": "clause1 && clause2" }
{ ..., "when": "clause3" }
```

benefits:
* fewer redundant-looking rules for extension authors to write
* easier for the user to override a keyboard shortcut if they don't have to hunt down the bindings for every when-clause combination.

data.title: keybinding when !editorTextFocus not triggering when Output window has focus
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.1
- OS Version: Win10

Following keybinding:

   {
        "key": "ctrl+c",
        "command": "workbench.action.tasks.terminate",
        "when": "!editorTextFocus"
    }

In 1.6.0 and 1.6.1 this keybinding would allow me to ctrl-c if I had the Output pane focused.  Now I have to specifically unfocus all elements by clicking on some border, to be able to use this keybinding.

I am not positive if it worked in 1.7.0, but I believe it did. 

(i would also be happy to accept a "when" outputPaneFocused .. or outputPaneFocused && (buildTaskRunning || testTaskRunning) .. something like that. )

data.title: Running node-sass inside an extension?
data.body:
I'm trying to use node-sass inside a vscode extension but I'm getting this error:

> Node Sass does not yet support your current environment: OS X 64-bit with Unsupported runtime (49)

I suppose that it's because I use my local node version to install node-sass but vscode executes it with it's own node version...

Is there any way to fix that?

data.title: Intellisense showing useless hints first, and useful hints last
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.1
- OS Version: win 7

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Load a javascript file to test the 'for' loop
2. Enter 'for' (if Intellisense doesn't show then press cntrl+space)
3. The first entry in the Intellisense is 'for' and when selected doesn't do anything
4. However the last few entries in the Intellisense are useful, there is a 'for' entry towards the bottom of the list, when select will add the following snippet:

for (var index = 0; index < array.length; index++) {
    var element = array[index];
}

5. This is what i want but why is it right at the bottom of the list?

data.title: The default selected item in completed items list is not consistent
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.1
- OS Version: Windows and Mac
- Extension: Go
- Customized Settings: None
- User defined Snippets: None

Below is a sample Go code with variables whose name start with `f` or `m`

Type either `f` or `m`, auto complete gives a list of completion items alphabetically sorted as expected.
But, the default selected item is different.
In case of `m` it is the first completion item
In case of `f` it is the first completion item of type snippet.

The Go extension provides the completion items, but as far as I know, it doesn't have a say in which of the completion items is selected by default.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16890566/19987804/33c4305a-a1da-11e6-8457-08ede9a0c379.png)

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16890566/19987823/4568a566-a1da-11e6-9473-af7e703bae5d.png)

data.title: Typescript + Divide operator make syntax highlighting goes wrong...
data.body:
I'm having an issue with my code with the new version **(1.7.1)**, divide operator isn't correctly highlighted and cause problems to the rest of the code.

**Screenshots:**

**With divide operator** `/`

http://image.prntscr.com/image/450c3ed8706d452b9872dea8379ef6e3.png

![With divide](http://image.prntscr.com/image/450c3ed8706d452b9872dea8379ef6e3.png)


**Without divide operator, replaced by**  `+`

http://image.prntscr.com/image/627da1a2cf7f46d292f66bbef4a64149.png

![Without divide](http://image.prntscr.com/image/627da1a2cf7f46d292f66bbef4a64149.png)


- VSCode Version: 1.7.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1.  Use this code with Typescript in a class (or not, but mine is inside a class function) and you'll see by yourself: 

```
var process = Math.max(0, Math.min(1, (Time - User.LastMove) % (1000 / User.Speed) / (1000 / User.Speed)));

if(times > 100000 || times < 0) {
       times = 0;
}
```

Please fix this!

**EDIT**

Seems it's only occuring when the next operation is a divide
Check this:
![img](http://image.prntscr.com/image/e124cacfd1984d3f936f7d2a68d6d10d.png)

And

![img](http://image.prntscr.com/image/7290c796b4084a609a5ca65823874e25.png)

Also 
`/ /`
is considered as a JSON (I've seen the class with the devtools) and has the same color as the image before
